title: IsDComplete Definition
content: **IsDComplete**: A set A is d-complete if eventually all n are representable as sums of distinct antichain elements from A. The antichain condition means no element in the sum divides another.

title: Powers23 Set
content: **Powers23**: The set {2^k · 3^l : k, l ≥ 0} = {1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9, 12, 16, 18, ...}. These are exactly the positive integers whose only prime factors are 2 and 3.

title: Closure Under Doubling
content: **double_mem_Powers23**: If n ∈ Powers23, then 2n ∈ Powers23. This is the key closure property used in the even case of induction: 2^k·3^l becomes 2^{k+1}·3^l.

title: Divisibility Characterization
content: **Powers23_dvd_iff**: The divisibility characterization. For 2^k₁·3^l₁ to divide 2^k₂·3^l₂, we need BOTH k₁ ≤ k₂ AND l₁ ≤ l₂. This follows from unique factorization: the 2-adic and 3-adic valuations must both be compatible.

title: Antichain Pairs
content: **Powers23_antichain_pair**: When k₁ < k₂ but l₂ < l₁ (exponents 'cross'), neither element divides the other. This creates antichain pairs and is crucial for constructing d-complete representations.

title: Largest Power of 3
content: **largestPow3**: Returns 3^(log_3 n), the largest power of 3 not exceeding n. Used in the odd case: subtracting this from an odd n gives an even number (odd - odd = even).

title: Powers of 3 are Odd
content: **pow_three_odd**: All powers of 3 are odd. Proof by induction: 3^0 = 1 is odd; odd × 3 = odd. This is essential for the parity argument in the main induction.

title: Parity Argument
content: **odd_sub_largest_pow3_even**: For odd n > 1, n - largestPow3(n) is even. Since both n and 3^k are odd, their difference is even. This enables the recursive call in the odd case.

title: Main Representation Axiom
content: **powers23_repr** (axiom): Every n ≥ 1 has a d-complete representation. The proof sketch uses strong induction with even/odd case split: double the representation of n/2 for even n; subtract largest 3^k and add it to the representation for odd n.

title: Main Theorem
content: **powers_2_3_dComplete**: The main theorem! The set {2^k · 3^l} is d-complete. This follows immediately from powers23_repr using the eventually_atTop filter characterization.

title: Pairwise Coprime and PowersABC
content: **PairwiseCoprime**: Three integers a, b, c are pairwise coprime if gcd(a,b) = gcd(b,c) = gcd(a,c) = 1. **PowersABC**: The generalized set {a^i · b^j · c^k}.

title: General Conjecture
content: **erdos_123_conjecture** (OPEN): For any pairwise coprime a, b, c > 1, is {a^i · b^j · c^k} d-complete? This remains unsolved despite progress on specific cases like {3^i · 5^j · 7^k}.

title: Erdős-Lewin Result
content: **erdos_lewin_357** (axiom): Erdős-Lewin (1996) proved that {3^i · 5^j · 7^k} is d-complete. The proof is more complex than the {2, 3} case due to the lack of a simple parity argument.

title: Scaling Preserves Divisibility
content: **dvd_iff_two_mul_dvd**: Divisibility is preserved by uniform scaling: a | b ⟺ 2a | 2b. This is the key to showing that doubling an antichain produces an antichain.

title: Antichain Doubling
content: **antichain_double**: If S is a divisibility antichain, then {2s : s ∈ S} is also an antichain. Combined with double_mem_Powers23, this shows the doubling step preserves d-complete structure.
